children.value: is one of the most important data analysis tools in Python for data processing. Built on NumPy, it offers many methods for handling large datasets and allows flexible, efficient data manipulation.
The main data type used in pandas is the
, which is a two-dimensional structure similar to a table in Excel. To use pandas, you first need to import it. In fact, the name ‘Pandas’ is short for ‘panel data’.
For example, consider the following data:
In general, there are two ways to create a DataFrame.

data.name: stdout
data.text:
Name  Statistics  Accounting  Marketing
0   Jim          85          82         84
1  Lily          68          63         90
2  Jack          90          88         78

children.value: Another way to create DataFrame with argument

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

data = np.array([["Jim", 85, 82, 84], ["Lily", 68, 63, 90], ["Jack", 90, 88, 78]])
df2 = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=["Name", "Statistics", "Accounting", "Marketing"])
df2

text/html.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0 Jim 85 82 84
1 Lily 68 63 90
2 Jack 90 88 78

text/plain.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0   Jim         85         82        84
1  Lily         68         63        90
2  Jack         90         88        78

children.value: Another way to create DataFrame with both argumens

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

data = np.array([[85, 82, 84], [68, 63, 90], [90, 88, 78]])
columns=["Statistics", "Accounting", "Marketing"]
index=["Jim", "Lily", "Jack"]
df3 = pd.DataFrame(
    data,
    index=index,
    columns=columns
)
df3

text/html.content:
Statistics Accounting Marketing
Jim 85 82 84
Lily 68 63 90
Jack 90 88 78

text/plain.content:
Statistics  Accounting  Marketing
Jim           85          82         84
Lily          68          63         90
Jack          90          88         78

children.value: In the above outputs, the first row are column lables while the first column are row indices. We can visit them by

text/plain.content: Index(['Name', 'Statistics', 'Accounting', 'Marketing'], dtype='object')
RangeIndex(start=0, stop=3, step=1)

children.value: One column or row data of a DataFrame is called a

text/plain.content: pandas.core.series.Series

children.value: Get the number of rows and columns in a DataFrame by
Get the number of cells in a DataFrame by
Get the data types of each column by

text/plain.content:
Name          object
Statistics     int64
Accounting     int64
Marketing      int64
dtype: object

children.value: Pandas also supports converting one-dimensional or two-dimensional arrays/lists directly into DataFrame format.

text/html.content:
0
0 1
1 2
2 3

0 1 2
0 1 2 3
1 4 5 6

children.value: In most cases, we need to read data files (such as Excel files). Suppose the example above is saved in an Excel file named ‘transcripts.xlsx’ located in the “datas/” directory on your computer. We can read the file using the

import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_excel("datas/transcripts.xlsx")
# or df = pd.read_excel("datas\\transcripts.xlsx")
# or df = pd.read_excel(r"datas\transcripts.xlsx")
File paths on macOS use the forward slash
as a separator, while Windows uses the backslash
before a file path string (e.g., r"path") preserves the original meaning of the string and prevents special characters from being escaped.
read_excel(io, sheetname=0, header=0, skiprows=None, index_col=None, encoding=None)
The file path and name of the data file, usually provided as a string.
The name or index of the worksheet. Defaults to 0, which reads the first sheet.
The row to use as column names. Defaults to 0, meaning the first row is used as headers.
Number of rows to skip from the top of the file.
Column to use as the row labels of the DataFrame.
When reading certain data files, you may need to add the decoding argument
Another common data file format is CSV (CSV is short for comma separated values). We can simply use Pandas’
method, whose syntax is essentially the same as
files, typically by specifying the separator using the
method. For example, to save our DataFrame df to the “datas/” folder with the filename “marks.xlsx”:
The folder must first exists in the computer before using
By default, the row indeices are not written to the file. If you want to include the index in the saved file, you can set
To quickly view the statistical summary of each column in a DataFrame, you can use the
method. It includes information such as the number of non-null values, mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, and quartiles for each column.

text/html.content:
Statistics Accounting Marketing
count 3.000000 3.000000 3.0
mean 81.000000 77.666667 84.0
std 11.532563 13.051181 6.0
min 68.000000 63.000000 78.0
25% 76.500000 72.500000 81.0
50% 85.000000 82.000000 84.0
75% 87.500000 85.000000 87.0
max 90.000000 88.000000 90.0

View the data type of each column
View the first n (default is 5) rows of the data
View the last n (default is 5)rows of the data

children.value: Access the data of a single row, column or cell

children.label: Access the data of a single row, column or cell

children.value: The simplest way to view a specific column of data is by entering the column name within square brackets
. For example, to view the ‘Marketing’ scores column:

text/plain.content:
0    84
1    90
2    78
Name: Marketing, dtype: int64

children.value: To view a particular row of data, use the
df.loc[0]  # show the data of the first row

text/plain.content:
Name          Jim
Statistics     85
Accounting     82
Marketing      84
Name: 0, dtype: object

children.value: df.loc[2]  # show the data of the 3rd row

text/plain.content:
Name          Jack
Statistics      90
Accounting      88
Marketing       78
Name: 2, dtype: object

children.value: To view a specific cell, a convenient method is to use double square brackets
, with the column label and row index inside each bracket respectively; Another way is to put the row index and column label insider
To view multiple rows and columns of data, you can use
, which not only allows accessing multiple rows and columns but also supports retrieving single rows, single columns, or even individual cell data.。
df.iloc[1] # view the data in the 2nd row

text/plain.content:
Name          Lily
Statistics      68
Accounting      63
Marketing       90
Name: 1, dtype: object

children.label: View the statistical values of the data

children.value: Pandas provides built-in statistical method to calculate summary statistics for column data. These method include:
, and more. In some cases, you may need to specify the argument
to ensure the method is only applied to numeric columns.
Sometimes we may need to cast the data types to numeric before using those methods.

# to calculate the average score for each course
# since the first column ('names') is non-numeric, the argument numeric_only=True is added.`
df.mean(numeric_only=True)

text/plain.content:
Statistics    81.000000
Accounting    77.666667
Marketing     84.000000
dtype: float64

children.value: Using ‘axis=1’ to apply the function to rows
df.mean(numeric_only=True, axis=1)  # computer the average score of each student
When modifying data in a pandas DataFrame, you can assign new values based on pandas index positions:
either assigning a column/row to a single value or to a list with equal length

df["Accounting"] = 80  # revise all the accounting scores to 80
df

children.value: When processing data, it is often necessary to perform batch operations on outliers or erroneous values in the raw data. Pandas provides the replace method to facilitate this task conveniently. The first argument of the replace method is the original value in the data, and the second argument is the value to be replaced.
For example, consider the following student grades:

import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame(
    [[55, 68, 70], [52, 63, 68], [74, 60, 58]],
    columns=["Statistics", "Python", "Finance"],
    index=["Jack", "Lily", "Tom"],
)
df

text/html.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55 68 70
Lily 52 63 68
Tom 74 60 58

text/plain.content:
Statistics  Python  Finance
Jack          55      68       70
Lily          52      63       68
Tom           74      60       58

text/html.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55 68 70
Lily 52 63 68
Tom 74 60 58

text/plain.content:
Statistics  Python  Finance
Jack          55      68       70
Lily          52      63       68
Tom           74      60       58

children.value: The original data does not change. To change the original data, we need addtional argument

text/html.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55 65 70
Lily 52 63 65
Tom 74 60 58

text/plain.content:
Statistics  Python  Finance
Jack          55      65       70
Lily          52      63       65
Tom           74      60       58

children.value: method to batch replace missing values (NaN) in a data table.
When reading some data files by Pandas, some blank cells will be treated as Numpy’s NaN (Not a Number) type.

import numpy as np

df = pd.DataFrame(
    np.array([[55, 68, 70], [52,  np.nan, 68], [74, 60, np.nan]]),
    columns=["Statistics", "Python", "Finance"],
    index=["Jack", "Lily", "Tom"],
)
df

text/html.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55 68 70
Lily 52 nan 68
Tom 74 60 NaN

text/plain.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack         55     68      70
Lily         52    nan      68
Tom          74     60     NaN

text/html.content:
Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55.0 68.0 70.0
Lily 52.0 80.0 68.0
Tom 74.0 60.0 80.0

text/plain.content:
Statistics  Python  Finance
Jack        55.0    68.0     70.0
Lily        52.0    80.0     68.0
Tom         74.0    60.0     80.0

text/plain.content:
Jack    False
Lily    False
Tom      True
Name: Finance, dtype: bool

children.value: Frquently, we need to perform data transformations on raw data. For example, if some numerical values in the original data are stored as text, we must convert them into numeric types before performing subsequent calculations. A commonly used method for data type conversion is

import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame(
    [["55", "68", "70"], ["52", "63", "68"], ["74", "60", "58"]],
    columns=["Statistics", "Python", "Finance"],
    index=["Jack", "Lily", "Tom"],
)
df

Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55 68 70
Lily 52 63 68
Tom 74 60 58

Jack         55     68      70
Lily         52     63      68
Tom          74     60      58

children.value: We can also change the data type to string or integer by modifying the argument of
When dealing with large datasets, duplicate data is a common issue. The
method can be used to remove redundant entries. For example:

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

data = np.array([["Jim", 85, 82, 84], ["Jim", 85, 82, 84], ["Lily", 68, 63, 90], ["Jack", 90, 88, 78]])
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=["Name", "Statistics", "Accounting", "Marketing"])
df

text/html.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0 Jim 85 82 84
1 Jim 85 82 84
2 Lily 68 63 90
3 Jack 90 88 78

text/plain.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0   Jim         85         82        84
1   Jim         85         82        84
2  Lily         68         63        90
3  Jack         90         88        78

text/html.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0 Jim 85 82 84
2 Lily 68 63 90
3 Jack 90 88 78

text/plain.content:
Name Statistics Accounting Marketing
0   Jim         85         82        84
2  Lily         68         63        90
3  Jack         90         88        78

children.value: The syntax of drop_duplicates is as follows:
'first': Keep first occurrence, remove subsequent duplicates (default)
'last': Keep last occurrence, remove previous duplicates
If True, modifies the DataFrame in place without returning a new object
If True, the resulting DataFrame's index will be relabeled (default False)
can drop the missing values in a Dataframe. Its syntax is as follows:
axis=0 drops rows containing missing values, axis=1 drops columns containing missing values
Default how='any': drops row/column if any values are missing
how='all': drops row/column only if all values are missing
Minimum number of non-missing values required to keep the row/column
If True, modifies the DataFrame in place without returning a new object
If True, the resulting DataFrame's index will be reset (default False)

import numpy as np

df = pd.DataFrame(
    np.array([[55, 68, 70], [52,  np.nan, 68], [74, 60, np.nan]]),
    columns=["Statistics", "Python", "Finance"],
    index=["Jack", "Lily", "Tom"],
)
df

Statistics Python Finance
Jack 55.0 68.0 70.0
Lily 52.0 NaN 68.0
Tom 74.0 60.0 NaN

Lily        52.0     NaN     68.0
Tom         74.0    60.0      NaN

children.value: When working with data, we may sometimes need to rename the row or column labels. This is where the rename function comes into play. The rename function takes a dictionary as its argument, where:
The dictionary keys represent the current names (to be replaced).
The dictionary values represent the new names.
to specify changing the names of columns or rows

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

data = np.array([["Jim", 85, 82, 84], ["Lily", 68, 63, 90], ["Jack", 90, 88, 78]])
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=["Name", "Statistics", "Accounting", "Marketing"])
df

children.value: In Pandas, two commonly used method for combining datasets are concat and merge.
Use concat when the two DataFrames have identical column labels.
In other cases, merge is typically preferred.

children.value: When df1 and df3 share the same ‘Name’ column but have different other column names, and we want to add df3’s columns to df1, we should use the
method. The typical syntax is as follows:
Default 'inner': performs inner join, merging only matching keys from both DataFrames
'outer': performs full outer join, merging all keys from both DataFrames
'left': performs left join, preserving all keys from the left DataFrame
'right': performs right join, preserving all keys from the right DataFrame
Column labels to join on (single or multiple)
So, for df1 and df3, when using

children.value: When querying DataFrame data based on certain conditions, some comparison operators are commonly used, such as:
. Conditional queries are generally applied only to column data. During the query process,
Pandas first generates a Boolean index (True or False)
and then produces the queried data by specifying this index.

children.value: When working with data, sorting is often necessary. Pandas provides a convenient method called
for sorting numerical data. Its syntax is as follows:
DataFrame.sort_values(by, axis=0, ascending=True, inplace=False, na_position='last', ignore_index=False)
Column labels to sort by (axis=0) or row indices (axis=1); multiple values allowed
0 for column-wise sorting, 1 for row-wise sorting (default: 0)
Sort order: True for ascending, False for descending (default: True)
Whether to modify the DataFrame in place (default: False)
If True, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, ..., n-1 (default: False)
Sort the scores of Statistics in ascending order.

0 Jim 85 82 84

children.value: Output data to a NumPy array or a list

children.label: Output data to a NumPy array or a list

children.value: method can convert DataFrame data into a NumPy array format. For example, using the previous data example:
method to convert a column of data into Python’s native list type.
to apply a function/method to the data.

import numpy as np

df["Statistics"].apply(np.sqrt)  # apply the method sqrt in NumPy to compute the squre root of a colun
We can also self define a

df["new Statistics"] = df["Statistics"].apply(lambda x: x - 10) # minus every score in "Statistics" by 10 to a new column
df

children.value: In practical work, we often encounter large amounts of time series data. The raw time series data is typically in text format, which needs to be converted into datetime format. Pandas provides the
method to convert other datetime formats into Python’s datetime format. For example:

import pandas as pd

pd.to_datetime("20200514") # transfor the date text "20200514" to Timestamp format
In the code above, we can see that the
method converts different types of time-related string data into the Timestamp format:
, can convert Pandas Timestamp data into strings of other formats. For example:

text/html.content:
Enrollment date Statistics Python Finance
0 2016-09-15 65 62 64
1 2017-03-23 58 63 60
2 2018-09-05 70 78 78

Enrollment date  Statistics  Python  Finance
0      2016-09-15          65      62       64
1      2017-03-23          58      63       60
2      2018-09-05          70      78       78

children.value: For many time-series datasets, it’s often necessary to aggregate data at specific periodic intervals. This can be achieved using Pandas’
method. To use this method, the DataFrame must have a datetime-like index.
* means this section may not be delivered in class.
Only having a datetime-like column is not enough, the index of the DataFrame must be a datetime-like

import numpy as np

index = pd.date_range("12/24/2019", periods=10, freq="D")  # generate a date range
index

df = pd.DataFrame(np.arange(10), index=index)  # generate a DataFrame with data range as index
df

text/html.content:
0
2019-12-24 0
2019-12-25 1
2019-12-26 2
2019-12-27 3
2019-12-28 4
2019-12-29 5
2019-12-30 6
2019-12-31 7
2020-01-01 8
2020-01-02 9

children.value: df.resample("ME").sum()  # use resample to sum the data every month

text/html.content:
0
2019-12-31 28
2020-01-31 17

children.value: df.resample("3D").sum()  # use resample to sum the data every 3 days

text/html.content:
0
2019-12-24 3
2019-12-27 12
2019-12-30 21
2020-01-02 9

children.value: df.resample("W").sum()  # use resample to sum the data every week

text/html.content:
0
2019-12-29 15
2020-01-05 30

children.value: represents hours. Besides being used with the
method, it can also be combined with:
→ Returns the value at the specified frequency (without aggregation).
→ Forward fills missing values after resampling.
In addition to visualization with Matplotlib and Seaborn, Pandas also provides its own plotting function plot(). The basic syntax is as follows:
Whether to generate separate subplots for each column (True/False)
We load a dataset ‘iris’ from seaborn.

import seaborn as sns

df = sns.load_dataset('iris')
df

children.value: Pandas provides a comprehensive set of data processing methods with numerous argument configurations. Due to space limitations, this book does not elaborate on them in detail. When using Pandas for data processing, readers are encouraged to consult the
How to creat a DataFrame ‘df’ for the following panel data?

import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'Nation': ['UK', 'US', 'China'], 'Capital': ['London', 'Washinton DC', 'Beijing']})

import pandas as pd
import numpy as pd

data = np.array([['UK', 'US', 'China'], ['London', 'Washinton DC', 'Beijing']])
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['Nation', 'Capital'])

A.    To display the last few rows of a DataFrame

A.    Get the number of rows and columns

A.    Converts a DataFrame to a NumPy array

How to save a Pandas DataFrame ‘df’ to a CSV file ‘data.csv’?
How to output the first 10 rows of a DataFrame ‘df’?
What argument to put insider the method ‘dropna()’ to make sure that the changes are done for the original DataFrame ‘df’?
Which method for converting a column into Python’s date formats?
Use Pandas to achieve the following:
Put the above panel data to a Pandas DataFrame.
Drop the student row who has modul score less than 50 (< 50).
Output the average score, maximum score of each module for the remnant students.
Rank the remnant students by the average score of all modules.
Output the final result to a csv file in the D drive named ‘output.csv’.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

columns = ['Student', 'Module1', 'Module2', 'Module3']
data = np.array([['Stu1', 50, 45, 56], ['Stu2', 81, 76, 73], ['Stu3', 60, 65, 62],\
                 ['Stu4', 77, 58, 60], ['Stu5', 60, 59, 54], ['Stu6', 40, 55, 53],\
                 ['Stu7', 57, 65, 70]])

df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=columns)
df[['Module1', 'Module2', 'Module3']] = df[['Module1', 'Module2', 'Module3']].astype(float) # question1
df = df[(df['Module1']>50) &(df['Module2']>50) & (df['Module3']>50)] # question2
df['Average score'] = df.mean(numeric_only=True, axis = 1)
df['Max score'] = df.max(numeric_only=True, axis = 1) # question3
df = df.sort_values(by='Average score', ascending=False) # question4
df.reset_index(inplace=True)
df.to_csv('D:/output.csv') # question5
